Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Ruiz Food Products, Inc. (Ruiz Foods) owns and operates a commercial processing facility in Denison, Texas.  It is the policy of Ruiz Foods to comply with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and safety laws and regulations, and to conduct its business in an environmentally sound manner that avoids any unreasonable adverse impact on the environment or its neighboring community.



In keeping with this policy, Ruiz Foods has developed and implemented OSHA's Process Safety Management and EPA's Risk Management programs to ensure the safety of our employees and the surrounding community.  The Risk Management program includes procedures: (1) to identify potentially hazardous chemicals at the facility, (2) for maintaining a safe working environment and, thereby, help prevent the release of hazardous chemicals, and (3) for minimizing the consequences of a release should one occur.





Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Ruiz Foods, Denison facility, makes tortillas, burritos and other Mexican food products.  The major processes at the facility include flour handling and storage, ingredient mixing, baking and product packaging and distribution.  Raw materials are delivered to this facility by trucks.



The only RMP regulated chemical handled by Ruiz Food at the Denison facility is anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility in the refrigeration system for making, cooling and freezing food products.  The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop system.   Anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the facility by supplier tank trucks to initially charge the system and occasionally thereafter to top-off the system if needed, to replenish from periodic maintenance.  



Ruiz has in place policies and procedures for handling the ammonia at the facility.  In addition, this facility complies with the ANSI/ASHRAE-15 Standard for ammonia refrigeration.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps



The Ruiz Foods - Denison facility is subject to both EPA's Risk Management Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  Under both of these programs, the facility has outlined specific procedures that it follows to prevent or minimize the release of anhydrous ammonia to the environment.  Specifically, the facility has performed a process hazard analysis (PHA) of the ammonia system and will repeat this process at least every 5 years.  The purpose of the PHA is to provide a systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards associated with the ammonia system.  In addition, the facility performs regular training of its employees to ensure that the procedures developed for the safe use and handling of ammonia is adhered to all the time.  Finally, the facility has a regular inspection and maintenance program to ensure that the ammonia system is operated and maintained according to specific ammonia industry safety standards.  



It is Ruiz Foods' policy and belief that safe operating and maintenance practices and accident prevention programs are the key to obtaining safe operation and achieving accident prevention.





Five Year Accident History Update



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))." 



An investigation into the facility's accident history during the PHA study performed on July 1-2, 2015 revealed that there was one release over the previous five years (July 2010 - July 2015) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of

100 pounds in 24 hours or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.



On June 16, 2015, the packaging operations team noticed an ammonia odor at approximately 5:50 pm. They evacuated the area immediately and notified the maintenance refrigeration team. The maintenance refrigeration team investigated and noticed alarms for high pressure. They discovered one of the coils was damaged due to a manufacturing defect, and because the system was on vacuum mode, air was pulled into the system.



Maintenance teams began a controlled purge of the system through the Condensers to drive the high pressure down. Purging continued with constant monitoring around the facility until Saturday, June 20, 2015. The National Response Center was contacted and notified of the release. Approximately 1,500 pounds of ammonia was released. There were no injuries or offsite impacts.



Emergency Response Program



Ruiz Foods has devised a comprehensive emergency response program, designed to protect both employees and the community in the event of a release. The Ruiz Foods Emergency Response Policy focuses on evacuation of the facility in the event of an ammonia emergency, with the assistance of local emergency response agencies performing rescue, firefighting, first-aid, medical treatment, and other response functions. The facility maintains a written Emergency Action Plan that documents specific procedures to be implemented in the event of various emergencies, including ammonia releases.  The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for facility evacuation, as well as notification of the local emergency response agencies that are responsible for notifying the public. The plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the facility that would require modified procedures.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) performed on September 13, 2005 and the following PHA Revalidation, performed on Jun

e 28 & 29, 2010, MOC PHA performed on May 15, 2014, and PHA Revalidation performed on July 1-2, 2015 generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve safety at the Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility located in Denison, Texas.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspections, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures. The Ruiz Food Products, Inc.'s safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their  employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
